p: Studies performed in mice have demonstrated the predominant protective role played by sIgA, 43, 44 even in case of absence of T cells. 45 Specifically, the passive intranasal transfer of anti‐influenza A IgA from the respiratory tract of mice immunized with live influenza virus has been seen to provide protection in naive mice. 43 Accordingly, this protection was suppressed by the intranasal instillation of anti‐IgA, 46 whereas it was not affected by treatment with anti‐IgM or anti‐IgG antibodies. This result supports the importance of IgA as a mediator of murine nasal anti‐influenza virus immunity in immunocompetent mice. 47
